message: do_something if some_condition?
Divide and conquer

I have a command-line app that I'm parsing a bunch of options out, so I have what looks like alot of if statements in a row

if something
  # do something
end
if an_additional_thing
  # do this other thing, too
end
if some_other_feature

What can I do that will make all of these 

if X
  # do X_thing
end
simpler?
lots of options :)
(some_condition) && do_something
def parseopt(condition, &b); yield if condition; end
(some_condition) ? do_something : nil
had to throw that in for completeness
if (some_condition) : do_something end
parseopt(1<2) {do_something}
Also, if you're looking a a lot of nested logic and processing and it looks like a general mess, you probably should extract some of that logic/processing into another class, file, or gem.
You might want to take a look at the thor gem to handle parameter parsing for you. It is a dependency of Rails so you might already have it installed.
@koraktor I forgot about that pattern.  That might work. :)
@peterheilberg I haven't looked at Thor.  I will give that a go.
For your specific case, go with thor
As a general rule, I would either use a case condition or an hash that maps to procs as @koraktor suggested

When I face so many "if" usually is because I have something wrong with my classes design. Objects should be "lazy", do small amount of work, and delegate other responsibilities to collaborators. Besides, maintaining a code full of "if" and hundred of lines per method  could be a pain... What about to refactor your code having in mind the Command or the Factory patterns?
then after that line, you can assume @account is not assigned. It can prevent future need for if statements.
return unless @account.nil? or something like that
I usually prefer a short circuited approach.
I also prefer short circuiting when possible

@cyaconi Yeah, in my case, there haven't been classes to design with.  It's really option parsing more like a command-line app that I want to build actions upon.  Going with @peterhellberg 's suggestion to try thor is probably a better option than trying to write it myself.  Great suggestions all around, though.

What brought about the question was looking at how things like OptionParser in Ruby core worked and forced you down the route of having to handle a bunch of different options.  If I had to nest options, things started looking ugly and I was getting frustrated with it's burgeoning lack of "Ruby-ness" to it.
code smell?
It's a code smell if I used alot of if statements, hence the point of this topic? :)

Check out: http://www.amazon.com/Refactoring-Improving-Design-Existing-Code/dp/0201485672 If you have a large number of if statements you like need to refactor to class composition. In ruby this can also be achieved with mix-ins to provide/override various functions. Dispatching from a hash like @koraktor suggests is also another alternative.
Yeah, I recently bought Eloquent Ruby by Russ Olson and I have been really loving the details he gives on module composition and inheritance.  Modules seem the way to go
